As far as Switzerland is concerned, residence is of the wage earner and based on where they spend most of their days.  Some countries, such as Germany, use a sort of "center of gravity" argument to attempt to collect tax, but this is usually when someone leaves Germany to work and their family remains behind in an owned property.     
I suggest you look at the residence threshold for the country you will be traveling to each weekend as they may want the difference between Swiss tax and their tax rate if you are deemed to be there too many days in a year.  Be aware that some countries consider the day you arrive and leave as a full-day in country, so arriving Friday night and leaving early Monday morning may count as 4 days by their rules and you'll find yourself owing some tax.  Have a look or consult a tax professional in the other country...money well spent.

I do agree with Kashel27 in all aspects, except the 'two small' cars.   
Two small cars do make more economic sense, except for 'practicality' and 'longevity' of the vehicle.   
Queenslanders typically do have a small "run around" car (the small car), and a larger family car (typically at least a 6 cylinder).   (when looking for rental property, you will see the abbreviation "DLUG", which means "Double Lock Up Garage")   
Keep in mind that driving in Australia involves exceptionally large distances and extremes of road temperature are very tough on the vehicle.   
Small cars have high revving, short stroke engines, which are great for start/stop driving. Larger engines have a longer stroke (Diesel in particular) so they do less work over distance. 
.... the thing is, small engine cars burn out if used on the highways more than larger cars.   
One large car is also useful in terms of lifestyle so you can pack up the family and all your stuff (eg. camping, or a day at the beach etc.).   
If you restrict the use of your larger car for long distances it's actually equally as fuel efficient as the small car.   (I know this for a fact. I had a 6L V8 Holden ute which used the same amount of fuel as a Toyota Corolla on a trip from Brisbane to Sydney)   
Australians don't like BIG cars like Americans, but we don't like small cars that burn out either.   
European cars are obviously fantastic vehicles, but unforunately Australia is a small and unimportant market for their distributers..... hence service, and price of parts become inhibitive to own these cars. Not to mention import tarriffs on purchase price.   
I used to drive 50,000km a year on average (which is a lot, but not as much as other people), so without the public transport system you have here in Switzerland, your car becomes an important choice which contributes to your lifestyle.   
Don't be afraid to own a 'big' car, just plan to use it wisely.

I browsed the internet for hours but still could not find a comprehensive list of things to do before you leave Switzerland. Therefore I decided to enlist all details of my own experience. I live in Lausanne, hence most of the terms pertaining to official documents will be in French, but I hope that this post will help people living in other parts of Switzerland as well. If you find additional points, please add them in the comments so that the reader sees everything.   
Once you decide to leave Switzerland for good, the first thing you should do is inform your housing agency (gérance) about the date on which you will give up your apartment. They demand a notice in writing, signed by both spouses/civil partners and sent to them by registered post. They do not recognize phone calls, normal mail and personal visits as proper means of notification. The housing agency will then inform you if about the next steps depending on the remaining duration of your contract. If they ask you to find new tenants, then you should start posting on social websites (and English Forum) or other places that you find suitable. I have heard that some agencies can be very nasty and demanding, hence it is better to give ample time to this aspect. Some ask for notice periods of upto 3-4 months. Please check with yours.   
The next step is to make a list of all the utility services that you use, and binding contracts. Some examples are: 
Bank 
Health insurance 
Electricity 
Cable/fixed line phone 
Mobile service provider 
Internet provider 
Household insurance 
Pension 
Employer 
Etc.   
Draft a letter to each office clearly indicating the date of your final departure from Switzerland. You should also put your new address and email i.d. in the letter so that they can communicate with you if needed. New bank account details should be included in case you are expecting a reimbursement, but do not send them yet.  All of them will demand copies of the Certificate of departure from the Permit office (Controle des habitants). This is the office where you applied for your residence permit upon arrival. This departure certificate cannot be issued more than 30 days before your departure date; hence you can only get it, at most a month before you leave. In Lausanne, they charge 20 chf and give the certificate within a few minutes.    
Once you get the departure certificate, make plenty of copies and append them to the letters that you drafted for cancellation of services and contracts. Most of the companies will not charge any fee or penalty for breaking the contract if you leave the country (that is why they require the departure certificate). All documents must be sent via registered post. If you have the time to go to the office in person, demand a cancellation confirmation.    
It is possible to keep your Swiss bank account running for a few months after your departure from Switzerland. You should contact a bank representative as soon as you have a moving date. This costs some money but is ideal for reimbursements (like pension) that will be faster for a Swiss bank account than a foreign bank account.   
While you are cleaning and emptying your apartment, you may want to either ship the furniture and other stuff to your new residence or sell it/give it away. In either case, you should check out the forum for recommendation in movers and advertising sites. For the household stuff that has to be discarded, there are few options. First, you may take these items to a nearby garbage collection centre (dechetterie) and dump everything there. For using the centre, you need to have a card that is issued free of cost by the canton. For example, in Lausanne, we can apply for the card at :     
Another option is to use the mobile waste collection vans. It is forbidden to throw bulky waste (of any sort) along the dustbins kept in front of each building. But once a month, there are mobile collection centres for all major parts in the city where you can dispose all kinds of waste (furniture, electric appliances, textiles, aluminium, iron, batteries etc.). Each canton should have a schedule for this service. For Lausanne, it can be found at:     
There are fixed garbage collection bins installed at some points in cities where people can routinely segregate and discard waste. A list of these fixed points can also be found in the above links.   
If you want to donate household items, there are some charity organizations like Salvation Army (more can be searched online) that can be contacted and booked for picking up your stuff from home. But these organizations are generally picky about the stuff they take, and should be contacted a few weeks in advance. Please note that they only take items that are not broken or damaged.  If something is unusable, they will not take it. Sometimes, they may be requested for disposing waste material for you, but they will charge you for this service.   
Once your apartment is empty, you need to clean it before handing it over to your housing agency. Sometimes, they are very strict about cleanliness of the house, so you should be very careful. Some people scrub and clean the house themselves, while others prefer to hire a professional for the service. Either way is fine as long as the house is clean enough for the inspecting people. Otherwise they charge you extra money. Some recommendations for cleaners may be found on the forum, but it is also good to ask around at your workplace or in your social circle. Inspection day is quite important. The housing agency makes a bill for the damages done to the apartment during your stay. It can be (partly or completely) reimbursed by the household insurance, so please keep track of all the documents that you receive.   
It is important to go to the post office near your domicile and inform them about the change of your address. They usually charge a fee (depending on the country you will move to) and direct the mail that arrives to your Swiss address to your new address for one year.   
I have tried to include everything that I have done so far. Incase I remember something else, I will post it below in the comments. Special thanks to English Forum and its members who have answered most of my questions during my stay in Switzerland.    
Cheers!!

I think that London is a fabulous city and a great place to live in if you're young or rich, preferably both    
There are lots of entertainment possibilities - great pubs, restaurants for virtually every conceivable taste and pocket, great museums (many of them free), clubs, cinemas, IMAX etc. Lots of great parks too. More opportunities for shopping than you can dream of.   
Flights out of London are numerous, direct to most destinations and overall good value.   
Not to mention that the UK itself has lots of things to see and do.   
There are downsides, too. London specific: be prepared to spend large amounts of time in travel (best to live as close as possible to your workplace). Meeting your friends might involve serious planning. On your budget you might flat share and live in a very small place (especially by Swiss standards). London is not car-friendly.   
While most of the city centre and a couple of other (rich) areas are stunningly beautiful, many, many residential areas in London are ugly and feel unsafe. Crime is much higher than in Switzerland.   
London is a very multicultural and racially diverse city (Brits being a minority), which you might like or not, as it has advantages and disadvantages.   
Taxes are high (even for a relatively small wage, and very high for a substantial wage) and paradoxically public services are quite poor. Transport is expensive. Property prices are horrendous, particularly in the better areas. Child care is very expensive (think of Swiss prices on UK wages).   
Personally, I think that living in London - if only for a little bit - is a great experience, particularly when you're young. It's different when you get older and your priorities change.

Thanks Kiwigeek but usually they don't ship in reverse and just have an agent or local partner in Switzerland which means you don't get the best rates.  As I'd mentioned in my original post which is probably buried somewhere now, it's better to deal with folks on the ground in Switzerland or interestingly the UK if you're shipping from here to Australia and want the best rates.   
Ok, so I've done a fair bit of research and wanted to pay forward my newly discovered knowledge:   
Post Office - 
Cheapest method i found and reasonably quick is postage 2-3weeks delivery.  The big benefit is that you don't have to pay all the customs, arrivals, storage and quarantine fees this way as its already pre-cleared.   Costs are:   
Deutsch Post - 123 for 30kg box, dimensions (160cmx60cmx60cm - huge compared to all other post boxes I've looked at).  FYI - The max you can ship to Australia is 31.5kgs.  For English folks the number I found after much searching and talking to Munich and Frankfurt airport post offices is +49 89 97306945.  They are very helpful and confirmed that my online calculation was correct.   
Italian Post is a dark horse as I discovered a price chart online which had a 20kg box shipping as surface for 89 (it didn't mention box dimensions though which is important to me as my boxes are huge!).  In any case this is very cheap and if you speak Italian or can find an English speaking post office (hint: try airport post offices as they deal with foreigners and may speak English), it could be worth talking to them.   
French La Poste cost just over 200 for 20kg box via their parcel carrier named Collissimo, but I couldn't find a number to call them directly on (that worked from Switzerland) to see if they offered a different rate at their standard post office.  As they are more expensive than Switzerland I ruled them out of my search.   
Even with a van hire from Allocar vans (40per day on a Tue/Wed) as my extra large boxes won't fit in our SUV, the postal option with Deutsch post is still cheaper than all of the other options I explored.   
Sea freight - 
I would definitely have chosen this method of shipping had I had a larger shipment of goods and furniture.  As it stands, I got 3 quotes from ocean freight companies and the best by far was from movecorp.co.uk.  They quoted £625 for my shipment based on a weight of 171kg for my boxes which are 60cm x 45cm x 60cm, or i could choose an unlimited weight option for £675.  This quote was £400 less expensive than the other two I received and the good thing about this quote was that it included pick-up and delivery so a true end-to-end service.  The obvious negative thing about ocean shipping is that it takes 8-12weeks (or longer) and there's a risk that things may get damaged or broken, so you need to add insurance on top of the costs.   
Unaccompanied air freight - 
Buyer beware with this option as EmiratesCargo, Qantas freight and those I checked into all use external freight forwarders for individuals.  They provide quotes which are "CPT" (carriage paid to) to Melbourne airport (or your relevant destination airport in Australia), which means that you have to pay arrival fees on top of your quote such as electronic import terminal arrival charges (based on weight), break bulk and automation fees, customs electronic entry.  In addition you will also need to pay (where applicable) duty taxes/storage fees, quarantine, AQIS inspection, and obviously moving fees if you want a company to do it for you.   
World Freight, Geneva  (EmirateS Cargo) for 178kgs was around CH$1,100 including pick up in Lausanne.  On top of this they quoted AU$425 for handling arrival fees only (quarantine, storage, AQIS and moving we're extra and could be another AU$150-300).   
Sauvin Schmidt cost around CH$1075, including pick up from Lausanne. They do not have a partner in Melbourne to provide arrival fees (charged by the airlines) so you would need to do this yourself or contract somebody locally, and quarantine, storage, AQIS and removal isn't fees would be extra again.   
Anyway, I hope the above information is helpful to others who are assessing different options.

I had searched this forum, but had not found anything related to de-registering in Kanton Luzern permanently to the US, so here's what I learned today.   
I went to the Einwohnerdienste on Obergrundstrasse and stated that I was leaving Switzerland permanently on 26-May.  I asked the lady what the earliest I could de-register was.  She said, "We can do it today if you want.  To us it does not matter.  We will put your date of leaving on the printout form."   
The cost was 12 CHF.   
She asked me for an ID or passport (I used my residence permit) and an address back in the US.  She let me keep my residence permit, saying to return it to the Amt fuer Migration before I leave, or mail it back to them after I get back to the states.   
So there you go.  Apparently no limit to how early you can de-register in Kanton Luzern, and a very reasonable cost.  Keep in mind, this is for permanently leaving heading to the US.  There may be other costs/fees/deadlines if you're de-registering to move to another Kanton or to another country other than the US.

1) yes, as all others said before: Stay registered 
2) you are, technically speaking, still employed for the entire time of your gardening leave. Nobody cares if you are physically here, just as nobody cares if you go on a business trip. Keep at least a room in a shared apartment in Switzerland. 
3) If the gardening leave comes to an end and you have for whatever reason not found a job... register for the RAV. Here comes the crucial part: You do not have to go there more than say three weeks before you want to get paid (so all the "go there ASAP" posts you find on here are uninformed - I know from personal experience). So while you do not need to go there in the first seven of the eight months... you will need to apply for jobs. At least ten a month -  from the moment on that you know you will get unemployed - basically now. Keep a record of it and show it to the RAV when you go there.   
I know this sounds like a lot of work, but in reality it isn't - pumping out the same electronic CV ten times does not really take a lot of time - even if you aren't looking for a job. So yes, even if you plan to spend the first four months on an adventure trip in Thailand - send some applications. With a little practice you will find ads that sound completely reasonabel for the RAV counsellor who isn't an IT specialist but you know that you won't get invited for an interview...

We did the opposite and came here from HK. I LOVED HK, but for the complete opposite reasons that I love it here.   
It's dirty, smelly, crowded, muggy and constantly noisy. But it's such a vibrant and interesting place. It is a place where you can stay in your expat bubble and live very comfortably, or you can venture more into the oriental experience.   
The pollution is VERY BAD. Don't underestimate it. There are days where the kids are kept inside at school due to pollution. If anyone has asthma or skin problems, then they will be worse in HK. Also, the doctors will prescribe antibiotics and medicines more readily because the humidity and pollution make illnesses worse (I had 6 sinus infections in one year until I listened to my doctor and took medications).   
The expats are very very welcoming - we made friends really easily and quickly, and have lifelong friends from our time there. The chinese are more reserved but if you make the effort you will also get to know some locals. This is easier with the younger generation.   
There are alot of international schools BUT (and it's a big BUT), there are also long waiting lists. HKIS, for example, is one of the best but it is very hard to get into. They firstly give priority to siblings, then corporate debenture holders (ask your company if they're providing this), then private debenture holder (very expensive - can be worth more than Fr.200,000 - but is refundable upon leaving), then children coming from an American system, then AMCHAM members children, then the rest of us. Other schools can be similarly difficult to get into.    
Note that the German Swiss International School might be easier to get into if you're looking at the German stream (they also have an english stream which is also very difficult to get into as it is also one of the best). BTW, alot of schools test kids before accepting them (GSIS does). Even 3 year olds are tested at some schools.   
There are also many ESF schools which are partly private, partly govt funded. They are cheaper than private schools and work like a public school - they have to accept your child if you are native english speakers, live in their catchment area, and they have space. They are mostly good schools, but check on the number of native english speakers. They fill classes with chinese and other nationalities who want their children to have a private education. Some schools have too many non-english speakers, which results in the teachers spending alot of time on the language, and explaining work in simple terms.   
Regarding where to live. There are expats all over the place (although fewer in some parts of the New Territories). Stanley is nice and yes there would be slightly less pollution there than in Central or the Mid-levels, but it's still not good. I would work out schools before deciding where to live. Otherwise your kids could be spending over an hour on the bus. (BTW, not all the pollution comes from China. HK has alot of old trucks and cars that spew out black fumes.)   
We lived in a highrise and I also loved that. I missed the space and backyard, but our high rise (over 300 flats) was like a ready made suburb. We always met people with kids in the common areas and that's how we got to know people so quickly. The building had a big outdoor area (over 200m long) where the kids could meet and ride bikes/scooters, etc, and the parents sat outside chatting. We also had a pool, 2 outdoor playgrounds and one big indoor play area with a climbing jungle. If you have younger kids this is a haven. HK gets alot of rain, combine it with the pollution and heat, and there can be alot of days when you don't want to go out. This was a lifesaver for entertaining the kids on those types of days. We also had a gym, squash court, function rooms (for birthday parties, etc), etc.   
Most people have a live in "helper", which is great but it takes some getting used to. Nearly all flats/houses have a separate area/room for the helper.   
I could write so much more as it is a fantastic place, but PM me if you have more questions or want more info.   
Someone asked about Pok Fu Lam.....apart from Cyberport (huge development with lots of new flats and shopping centre, etc) it's a slightly cheaper area of HK as there is a cemetary there and the chinese don't like living near a cemetary. You get more value for your money, but again I would pick a school first. We have a friend in Pok Fu Lam and it takes her 7 year old son over an hour on the bus every day to and from GSIS. He gets on the bus at 6.20am every morning!!!!

April,  what is your nationality ?  If you have a EU passport you shouldn't need major paperwork to enter Spain. 1) De-register 
2) Pay off any and all debts 
3) Remember to cancel all services you have hired (cable, phone, internet, Bilag, insurance, cell phone, etc) 
4) Since you are moving INTO the EU, Spain will require a whole bunch of documents to accept your importing so many household goods. 5) Super important if you ever want to go back to Switzerland: give them a forwarding address for them to send you your closing income tax statement.

post: You could be liable for Swiss income taxes till you de-register.

I got both my health insurance and car insurance re-imbursed when I sent them a letter that I was leaving the country a few years back.   
Now that I'm looking into moving back to CH, I got a bunch of quotes through these guys:    
Moving out: all depends on your contract. Moving dates could be anything from 3 dates a year to any last day of the month. Notice period is usually 3 months. If you can move out on any end of month and you give notice today, you will pay rent until 30.06.09.   
Deposit: tricky one. In theory, you should get your deposit back minus any expenses the landlord has to make for repairs over and above wear and tear. There's been books written about this and you can find plenty of threads to help (or scare) you.   
Good luck!
